On Fri, 14 Dec 2001 01:34:07 -0800, Cormac Mullally wrote:

>I
>need access to the file system to get the xml files but i don't want to
>hard code in the dir.

I'm using ResourceBundles for this. The advantage of that system
is, that the config-files can be packed into the jar-files, because they
are searched in directories/jars specified in the CLASSPATH.
The code in the JUnit-Tests looks like this:

[...]
/**
* Tests the functionality of MailManager
* @author "Lothar Kimmeringer" <lothar@...>
* @version 1.0
*/
public class __Test_MailManager extends TestCase {
private static java.util.ResourceBundle config;
[...]

static{
if (config == null){
config = java.util.ResourceBundle.getBundle("test/props/com_nuag_util_MailManager");
}
}

[...]

public void testSendStandardMail() throws Exception{
mail.sendMessage(config.getString("SMTP.Host"),
Integer.parseInt(config.getString("SMTP.Port")),
config.getString("Sender.Email"),
null,
new String[]{config.getString("Recipient.Email")},
null,
null,
"Test-Subject", "This is a test-message", null);
[...]


The resource-file looks like this:

- --- snip
SMTP.Host=polly
SMTP.Port=25
Sender.Email="Lothar Kimmeringer" <lothar@...>
Recipient.Email="Testuser at testmailer" <test@...>
CC.Email=
BCC.Email=
- --- snap

The name of the file can be specified as preferred. The format
com_nuag_util_MailManager allowes to put all files into one
directory without running into trouble if there are classes with
the same name in different packages (e.g. Event).


Hope that helps

Regards, Lothar

PS: To avoid comments on that TestCase-example. The mailmanager tested here
already uses the javax.mail-framework, so I'm aware of the existance ;-)
